title: Before 1 January 2018, will the European Commission find Google liable in an antitrust case?
preds:
Antitrust: Commission fines Google â‚¬2.42 billion for abusing dominance as search engine by giving illegal advantage to own comparison shopping service
http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-17-1784_en.htm
Google reportedly faces record US$1.1bn European Commission fine

It looks like this is going to happen by September: 
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/16/business/eu-google-antitrust-fine.html

When doing my initial research for this question I seem to have missed that the Google Search (Shopping) case was initiated in 2010 and not 2016... oh well better late than never I suppose. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-10/google-execs-hunker-down-for-summer-fight-with-eu-as-fines-loom

Significantly increasing my answer because of this Reuters story claiming there will be a resolution to these antitrust cases in the next few months. Certainly sounds like this year, and that Google will be found guilty.

It takes about 2 years for a "strong" case to go from "open investigation" to "finding". (Apple case by the same Commission). The investigation is formally open Dec 2016. The 1/6 odd reflects the possibility that the case is expedite due to political pressure, and the much higher average odd given by the respondents to this challenge so far.
Following the people I follow on this one. Haven't paid close enough attention personally.
My Dear Google, they got ya!

"OXFORD, England (Reuters) - EU antitrust regulators will rule in the "next few months" whether Alphabet's Google abused its dominance of internet searches and other areas, a senior European Commission official said on Monday, an outcome that could lead to a hefty fine."
One person does not decide this
Correction for past low rating, based on https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/504231
Should do but deep pockets to be an army of lawyers

I dont think, they'll be so fast. The case is very complicated and i believe, that they will merge the three cases in some way. That will take some time. Generally, there will be a settlement. The case is too complicated. google also won a case in Germany recently.

"As the EU’s Antitrust Chief, Margrethe Vestager, is expected to finalize the first of her three antitrust cases against Google’s abuses of dominance in June-July,..."
http://precursorblog.com/?q=content/google-takeaways-trump-antitrust-chief’s-senate-confirmation-hearing

EC has raised antitrust cases against Microsoft, Intel, and Rabmus from 2007 to today.
According to NY Times, battles between Google and EC has been going on for 6 years (2011)
Many EC officials are vocally critical of Google.

The cases under review seem fairly benign. Unless Europe is under political or economic threat as a result of Google, I think this is unlikely. Google and the Tech industry in the United States is capitalistic, but from a political perspective, Google and other tech giants in the US should seem favorable to Europe's democracy in terms of promoting transparency.
Inofficially, fore sure. Even on public-possibly.

The EU will back off going after US industrial champions, as this is in conflict with Trump's America First orientation. The EU needs Trump to move closer to the old orthodoxies of the US being the unequivocal supporter of EU and NATO.
Vestager of the EU's competition commission seems to be serious about going after Google.
Some nice info on the technicalities of the 'Search Engine' case: "Foundem: Remedies in the Google Search Case" http://www.foundem.co.uk/Foundem_Google_Search_Remedies_March_2017.pdf

Drastic change because of this quote from Bloomberg:
"Google is the highest-profile probe facing Vestager, whoâ€™s called 2017 her "G year" as she aims to conclude this case as well as a politically charged investigation into Russian gas supplier Gazprom."
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-24/eu-said-to-search-for-google-solution-that-stands-test-of-time
Timeline Seems fairly quick for a judgement.
Google are under pressure to play fair and the EU moves slowly. If they are talking they'll both want to avoid an antitrust case to resolve this

I lean a little toward yes in this question because the antitrust case for Google's comparison shopping service has now been going on for two years and so 2017 is within the normal range for a case to be wrapped up. Furthermore, the EC sees this case as setting valuable legal principles for net neutrality (see link). As well, considering the range of investigations, I think it's clear the EC believes Google is guilty, if not for this than for something.
In the past, it took 4 years to conclude the proceding against Microsoft.

I think that the EU is unlikely to find google liable for two reasons: 1) they may be merely voicing their concerns via a suit because the feel they have no leverage/bargaining power, otherwise, and 2) they may think that finding google liable may result in a functional decrease in access to services, which they want to avoid.
ToC and Fraud suggestions - while not antritrust - suggest speed and heat are moving to EU

Google, Facebook, Twitter must amend ToS for EU users or face fines
Trio given one month to clean up fraud, scams, and make other fixes.
https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/03/google-facebook-twitter-must-comply-with-eu-consumer-law/
Time is on Google's side. The complaints are from 2013-2016, but the case is too complex for a speedy conclusion.
Get Google. Someone has to stop the US mass surveillance in its tracks and the only way to do that is to punish Google.

EU consumer authorities to take on Facebook, Google, Twitter
European consumer protection authorities will ask social media companies Facebook, Google and Twitter to amend their terms of service within one month or possibly face fines, a source familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

Gazprom reaches draft antitrust deal with EU (FT)
Google next?
Initial guess. First article I read WSJ not too informative.

I am sure that the EU will find Google liable with the present legislation, the depth of resolution in this case was technically easy to make based on the data presented by experts. 
Now, the time frame for the resolution is too short for this question to be resolved with a 100% by January 1st. 2018. The EU started the Google case in 2010 and still have to resolve it. They started with opening proceedings in July 2016!
I expect a settlement with the EU opening their tithing bag and collect their 10%.......

Another complaint filed today by a group of internet companies including German newspapers, Axel Springer and a French search engine - various articles on it below. Also mentioned, the Turkish anti-trust investigator are now looking into Google. I think the chances of the EU acting on this are pretty high overt he next year. Frankly with Brexit and elections in France/Germany, I think the Commission may need to justify its existence and this would be a way of the commission protecting its members from the dastardly corporates.
http://www.pcworld.com/article/3177785/android/google-faces-another-antitrust-complaint-in-europe.html
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-google-antitrust-idUSKBN16E1VE
https://www.ft.com/content/03d5b950-05c8-11e4-8b94-00144feab7de

Apple, Google, Amazon and Facebook will be primary targets for their tax evasion and as retaliation against any US trade aggression. There is legislation being prepared to tax US (offshore)  companies in sales geography vs currently at domicile
Unclear strength of case at this time, precedent for cases taking longer for a decision, possibility of other conclusions other than liable in the end.
The link for more info lets you search over cases in the past.
It takes more time & Google should be able to fight it.
They will find them to be evil as well as all Google accounts (Chrome) and gmail accounts save credit information even if you delete it, Google will find it again. Pure evil. --Craig

I think they will be find liable. There's a confrontational attitude between the Europe and the US, and Europe is particularly weary of US Tech firms. It will happen, will it happen before 1-Jan-2018? Probably not. Google has strong legal prowess and they may be able to delay the whole process for a longer time

The case against Android's dominant position in the app market seems misguided and would set problematic precedents in the IT domain. The case against the presentation of ads in Google search is more credible, and the fact that some differing cases have been merged under this one case would suggest the Commission is putting a fair bit of resources into the investigation. The time it has taken in the past for resolution of IT antitrust cases in the EU has ranged from 1-4 years for companies such as Microsoft (on several occasions) and Intel. The proceedings in the latter Google case were opened in July 2016, hence the earliest we could expect a decision is in Autumn 2017. Given that these cases concern new technology and business models there will  not be many precedents to draw from making the process longer. In addition, Google has sufficient resources to mount a serious legal challenge to the investigation so can draw out the process further. In the end I think it's likely Google will end up having to slightly tweak its ads systems in the EU and pay a fine, but that won't be in 2017.

Europe is very suspicious of dominant US tech companies and I believe that google will be found liable. The main question is when. Google will want to delay as long as possible and there is no legal deadline for the European Commission to conclude this case so it may take a while longer.

Both the US and Europe are finding multinationals to be a good source of revenue beyond the normal tax collection.  Considering the amounts fined the European Banks by the US it will not be surprising to see similar actions against Alphabet, Microsoft and other US multinationals with significant accumulations of earnings outside the US often in Europe.  These types of fines are adjusted so as to maximize the collection without destroying the company.  Such as the US fine to the German bank and as will probably end of being the case with Volkswagen.  If a US tax holiday of say 10% on repatriated earnings by US companies comes into being as is being considered there will be a quick and massive return of this money to be used for dividend payout, loan paydown, stock buy back and maybe even investment in the business.  It will certainly be in part to remove these targeted pools of money from governments sight and reach.
So many cases, but Google's lawyers will delay. Don't expect a quick resolution.
